maker to hundreds of millions of customers on the snapchat form factor so
our mission at AWS with the machine learning is very similar to the mission that we've had at
AWS since the very beginning our original mission was to be able to take technology that was traditionally only
within reach of a very small number of well-funded organizations and put it in the hands of every single developer and
we've done that reasonably successfully with compute and with storage and databases and analytics and data
warehouses and we're taking the exact same approach with machine learning now machine learning it's still relatively
early and it's still a relatively nascent technology and so we've had to build an entirely new stack of
applications services and frameworks in order to be able to allow any developer and data scientist to start using
machine learning we think of this in three real tears at the bottom tier this
is the most technically advanced this is really the domain of research scientists and data scientists who are using
low-level machine learning frameworks usually open source called things like tensorflow and apache MX net pi torch
cafe to china and so on and these frameworks are the programming languages
for machine learning they allow you to specify your algorithm to design your neural networks and then go and train
them a very very large scale across large amounts of data and that each have their own sweet spot tensorflow has an
amazing community and is well represented on mobile MX net does really really well when you want to scale
particularly across multiple instances pi torch is great for prototyping cafe 2
is amazing for computer vision and what we found is that developers want to use all of these together it's just too
early in machine learning to want to specify a single framework and stick with it today two-thirds of developers
are using multiple engines in order to be able to get their real work done and our approach just as Vern on the same
before to not be paternalistic we want to support all of these frameworks as first-class citizens across the platform
this includes novel cutting-edge technologies such as Avadh which brings large-scale fast
distributed training to tensorflow which we added to AWS a couple weeks back are the next level up this is
really the realm of developers and data scientists who have data sat in s3 and want to be able to Train custom models
using that data and here we see customers using sage maker to build train and deploy custom models using
that data up in the cloud and also to be able to deploy it down at the edge and prototype with devices such as deep
lense so let's take a deeper dive into Amazon sage maker there's really just
three things you need to be able to do the first is you want to be able to train your model using custom data and to do this today you can bring up your
own algorithms you can just specify a container and give it to Sage maker and sage maker will handle all the training
and the distribution for the training job you can with just 20 lines of Python start running your own tensor flow or MX
net algorithm very easy or you can train with the built-in sage maker algorithms
now these built-in algorithms are one of the the miracles at the heart of sage
maker in my opinion they are designed for what we kind of half jokingly called infinite scale and there's a remarkably
broad set of capabilities inside sage maker which are available to you right off the bat things like cutting edge
deep learning driven object detection for computer vision or text classification which is accelerated with
GPUs we have multi class classifiers built right in there and we even brought
the forecasting algorithm what we use inside amazon.com for all our retail forecasting and put that right inside
sage maker as well it can handle billions of time series data to in order to be able to provide a very accurate
deep learning driven forecast going forwards and every single one of these built-in algorithms is designed to be
ten times better ten times faster ten times cheaper ten times more efficient
and that the core of that is the streaming data that we use so a common occurrence in
machine learning when you get started is you want to be able to take your data and you want to be able to put it near the compute so you can Ram run your
training on it very very quickly the trouble with that is you have to wait for the data which can be just like we heard with snap hundreds of terabytes
to copy over to your computer infrastructure it just is slow also it limits the amount of memory limits the
amount of data that you can use based on the algorithm so instead we take data and we stream it direct from s3 we don't
do any copies we stream it direct from s3 with a high throughput connection and we do a single pass train over the data
that means we just need to iterate over at once and because we're streaming it from s3 we can checkpoint our models at
any point in time and that allows us when we want to retrain or modify our model we just add more data to it we
don't have to start from scratch and all of this is available at the end of an API if you can call a lambda function
then you can do all of this inside sage maker literally this afternoon but one
of the things we hear from customers is how can we make our own algorithms algorithms that our data scientists and developers are building for our own
business as fast as the ones that are inside sage maker and the truth is today this is kind of cumbersome you can do it
but it's very very difficult to get right it's very hard to get the performance and it involves getting
really into the weeds or a whole bunch of low-level low-lying C++ code nobody's
got time for that and so today we're introducing a new feature which we call Amazon sage maker
streaming algorithms [Music]
streaming algorithms allow you to accelerate your own algorithms by taking the same approach we use for the sage
maker algorithms and stream large volumes of training data from Amazon s3 through your model this is great because
it allows you to stream it into your own algorithm it dramatically reduces by up
to 90% the amount of time it takes for your training to start because you don't have to do that copy step up front it
also means you can just drive more data onto your GPUs and your CPUs to drive your training that means they operate
more efficiently and it can cut down the time that it takes to run your training models and because on AWS everything is
metered and only pay-as-you-go every second counts so if you can reduce the training time you can dramatically reduce the training
costs so we're bringing this today to tensorflow and we'll be applying it to additional frameworks coming soon so once you have
trained your model add another step in machine learning is the optimization step and again just from the end of an
API you can run high powered machine learning driven parameter optimization which continually searches for the best
possible model for your training data once you've optimized most customers want to be able to host their model they
won't be able to put it into production and so we provide a be testing for those algorithms so you can deploy them safely
and we provide robust elastic hosting for those models right inside Sage Maker now the elastic hosting is as you would
expect very easy to integrate we take your model we deploy it onto a fully managed infrastructure and we give
you an easy to integrate API endpoint then you can drive low latency real time predictions using that model under the
hood will auto scale to make sure that we're providing the right level of capacity and we'll do that across
multiple AZ's to provide fault tolerance to the model so this is perfect for real-time low latency predictions but
there are some situations where customers want to be able to process a whole bunch of data just all at once
upfront in batch or where they have very very large files such as those medical imaging files that I was talking about
before or 5k video where they want to be able to process a big file all at once so today what we're well set up for real
time customers wanna be able to have more flexibility to train batch and large files and so today we're introducing a
new feature of sage maker which we call batch transform sage make a batch
transform provides fully managed high-throughput batch transform jobs with a simple API call so this means
that you can process data dumps in a batch if you have a new set of billing inventory if you have a whole bunch of
product sales you can just take that at the end of the day and just throw it against your model and start doing your predictions you can also process large
files five gigabytes and up much more easily without having to chunk them into pieces and what a lot of customers are
doing are using this approach to test their models so once they've trained the model they have a test set which is well
understood and they just run through that as a sanity check to make sure it works before they start rolling in into production through a/b tests and that
works if you want to run it in the cloud or if you're deploying those models say to an MRI machine which sits in a
hospital to run at the edge so the joy here is that you can use the exact same
models that you're training in Sage Maker today for real-time predictions and run the exact same models for batch
predictions and you can take all of the pre-processing and post-processing steps and bring those into your batch
processing workloads as well and again this is all fully managed if you've ever run a training job in sage maker this is
virtually the same API and so through all these capabilities the training the
optimization the hosting we see a dramatic decrease in time that it takes customers to take their machine learning
models train them up and put them into production Intuit are running close to real-time fraud analytics and driven by
machine learning on their platform routinely and they were able to reduce their deployment time down by 90 percent
using sage maker they used to take them six months to build a model and get the first version into production now they
can do it routinely in less than a week certain machine learning platforms at
the next level up we have a set of AI services these are really designed for application developers who don't want to

have to go and label a whole bunch of data they just want to get stuff done and you can see right off the bat you get this broad set of capabilities
available to you for computer vision using services such as Amazon recognition which provides

speech using poly which is a text-to-speech service the same service
that we use to generate the voice of Alexa or transcribe which does it the other way around it takes speech and
turns it into text or in terms of languages translate which takes text in
one language and translates it into another or comprehend which looks inside the document and all of the text takes

unstructured information all the way through to Amazon Lex which is a natural language understanding and speech
recognition system that a lot of customers are using to build chat BOTS or used in content centers as IVR
systems and Lex is the exact same beating heart that we use to run Alexa for the echo and other Alexa enabled
devices so whilst all of these services are designed to work independently and
have a broad set of capabilities themselves the real magic comes as customers start to pull them together
and they can be joined together for some common use cases so I just wanted to close out this section of the keynote
with just a few examples of the use cases that we're seeing and some of the trends so the first is really as I was
